turns.content: Serious question: Because of the international aspects of ACTA, is our country legally obligated to pass bills like SOPA and PIPA? (x/post from r/politics to try to get an answer)

No, countries are not legally obligated to pass bills like SOPA and PIPA because of the international aspects of ACTA (the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement). ACTA is a multilateral treaty that aims to establish international standards for the enforcement of intellectual property rights. It does not require countries to pass specific domestic legislation, and countries are free to determine their own approaches to addressing intellectual property violations within their own legal frameworks.

SOPA (the Stop Online Piracy Act) and PIPA (the Protect IP Act) were proposed legislation in the United States that aimed to address online copyright infringement and the sale of counterfeit goods. While ACTA may have influenced the development of these bills, the decision to pass or not pass them was ultimately up to the U.S. Congress and would not have been legally required by ACTA or any other international agreement.
